They did not think they should be investing in that process. The ABC had the option of, amongst its priorities, choosing to broadcast Radio Australia into that area. The ABC did not consider it a priority when they were making decisions about what was important to their budget or not. They preferred to keep the symphony orchestras. They preferred to keep all of their highly paid executive staff at North Sydney. They preferred to do all of those sorts of thingsârun their expensive television productionsâbut they did not consider it a priority to broadcast into South-East Asia.

So it has fallen to the government to maintain a presence in that area. As has been said by members of the House already, we have boosted the signal out of Shepparton into the Timor area. It is all very well for members of the Australian Labor Party to say, `We do not really mean "Timor" when we talk about this.' I would like to quote to members opposite the comments of Stephen Smith, the member for Perth and shadow minister for communications, who in a statement on 24 September said:
The recent tragic events in East Timor saw the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade issue warnings to Australian nationals living in Indonesia and East Timor.

There is the shadow minister for communications confusing the issue and thinking that signals from Cox Peninsula can in fact get into Timor. They cannot. Short-wave radio transmission is a hazardous thing in the best of circumstances, but to expect Cox Peninsula to broadcast into Timor is beyond any realism.

Radio Australia has made a decision to broadcast back into the Indonesian peninsula from Taiwan and Singapore. I think that that is a realistic process. It is a process that targets the area where Australia needs to have some information going out for six hours a day. I notice that Brian Johns, the senior executive officer of the ABC, has made statements about the adequacy of such a program.

To add further to the confusion about whether or not Cox Peninsulaâthe place that the Australian Labor Party wants to reopenâcan reach into East Timor, UNAMET has asked the federal government for urgent permission to use the Cox Peninsula transmission station, closed since 1997, so it can broadcast to the East Timorese as soon as possible. That is from a news report dated 24 September. It is absolutely wrong and badly informed. Anybody thinking that Cox Peninsula can broadcast into East Timor is wrong. What is needed is to establish as quickly as possible civil order in East Timor and to have the United Nations start to deal with a local radio station for the people of East Timor. What is needed is a radio station of the East Timorese for the East Timorese; not a foreign program beamed in from Australiaâfrom Shepparton, in fact, and not from Cox Peninsula. The Cox Peninsula project would cost $4,000 for each 12 hours it was kept open. It is a somewhat remote or difficult to get to site.
Mr Snowdon interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThe ferry costs $300 each way, so that is not an easily locatable site. The government's decision is a reasonable one in the circumstances. (Time expired)
âOrder! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate has adjourned, and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

subdebateinfo.title: East Timor: United Nations Transitional Administration

talk.start.para: âIt is not my intention to be distracted by the erroneous contribution of the previous speaker on the debate about the Cox Peninsula. Suffice it to say that I thought the opposition members involved in the debate put the case quite succinctly. I will make the observation, however, that anyone who believes Cox Peninsula is remote is themselves remote from reality. Nor do I want to contemplate at any great length the appalling way in which this government has handled our foreign policy in relation to East Timor. I do not want to recount my observations which had been made in this and other places about this issue over the past few weeks, but I would like to direct members of the parliament, particularly members of the government, to a very good article in today's Age by Robert Manne in which he points out the very obvious shortcomings of the government's diplomacy in relation to East Timor. I will just quote the penultimate paragraph of that article, in which he says:

speech.para: Why, then, did Australia fail to call on the Americans to warn Indonesia of the cost of violence in East Timor? Until the very end Australian diplomacy remained too concerned about the wounding of Indonesian sensibilities. Until the end it hoped against hope that somehow the special relationship with Indonesia could be preserved. The old appeasing habit of mind with regard to Indonesia died hard. If there is an explanation for the failure of our East Timor diplomacy it is to be found here.

I concur absolutely, 100 per cent, with that observation. This afternoon in question time we heard the Minister for Foreign Affairs responding to a question. He talked about a draft resolution which is to go before the Security Council as a result of a recommendation made to the Security Council by the Secretary-General. It is that that I want to talk about this afternoon. I want to note the thrust of the report of the Secretary-General on the situation in East Timor, the structure that it promotes in terms of its recommendations and its intent in terms of capacity building amongst the East Timorese. The principal recommendation is for the establishment of a new body to replace UNAMET. That new body will be known as the United Nations Transitional Administration in East TimorâUNTAET. In paragraph 28 of his report the Secretary-General says that the purpose of this body should be:

To establish the condition for sustainable peace and to facilitate the transition of East Timor to independence. It is proposed that UNTAET must be entrusted with a robust mandate containing the following elements:
. provide security and maintain law and order throughout the territory of East Timor;
. establish an effective administration;
. assist in the development of civil and social services;
. ensure the coordination and delivery of humanitarian assistance, rehabilitation and development assistance;
. support capacity building for self government;
. assist in the establishment of conditions for sustainable development.

That is a very comprehensive list, and we have here the opportunity for the United Nations to set up, in a quite unprecedented way, a new system of governance in consultation with the East Timorese community. It is that issue that I want to concentrate onâthe issue of the relationship between UNTAET and the East Timorese community.

This document from the Secretary-General is replete with words such as `consult', and the need to consult with the East Timorese is important but we need to include them at every level of decision making. The references to documentation in the document are not sufficient. We must have the Timorese involved in making all decisionsânow and beyond the time that they set up a new and independent government after the transitional period. They are, after all, the subject of our attention. The UN's resolutions, the humanitarian aid effort, the work being done by other sovereign governments and by independent and private organisations which are not NGOs are not the object of our attention. There is therefore a need to see the East Timorese as people with whom we should be negotiating at every step of the way. At the moment that is unfortunately not the case.

There are a number of fundamental questions about the language used by the United Nations or by the Secretary-General in his report. What in fact does consultation mean? How does the United Nations envisage that advisory bodies will be formed? I refer there to paragraph 30 of the Secretary-General's report in which he talks about the effectiveness of UNTAET `resting on its ability to perform its duties in close consultation and cooperation with the people of East Timor.' Later in the same paragraph he says:

Pending the holding of elections, the Special Representative will establish advisory bodies at all levels to ensure the participation of East Timorese in the governance and administration of the territory.

That is laudable, but it needs to happen as of now. It is not something which should be delayed, because we will have a period when UNAMET continues its operations until the decision by the Indonesian parliamentâwhich is expected shortlyâand subsequently, when the new United Nations body is properly formed and takes up its responsibilities.

It is clear that at the moment there is only one organisation that can argue that it represents the views of the vast majority of the East Timorese communityâthat is, the National Council for Timorese Resistance, CNRT, a coalition of forces under the presidency of Xanana Gusmao. Under the CNRT, he is the President of the National Political Commission. This body is already represented on the reconstruction committee set up inside East Timorâwith others, including INTERFET, UNAMET and the Catholic Church. It is imperative that, until an alternative representation operation is put in place, the representation which is made for the consideration of the East Timorese community comes from at least CNRT. Until the new body is put in place, the CNRT must be represented at the core of decision making by UNAMET and by the body to replace it, UNTAET.

The role of the special representative for governance and public administration under the new proposal is very important, because it gives that person the responsibility to set up, among other things, all managerial and representational functions of the mission. He will be responsible for and head the governance and public administration component of the organisation. In terms of the governance and public administration component, he or she will have two core objectives: to lay the foundations for sustainable institution of independent East Timor and to design an agenda for sustainable economic and social development.

It is absolutely imperative that at every stage of this operation the East Timorese community are part of the decision making process. CNRT represents the bulk of the East Timorese communityâat least in the context of the vote which took place on the question of independence from and integration with Indonesia. It needs to be understood that CNRT is a political alliance of a whole range of bodies which have drawn together to support the process of independence. There is an absolute and fundamental need for the United Nations and its agencies, other governments, the NGOs and other private organisations to be in constant dialogue with and in tune with the wishes of the Timorese community.

This also means those business people who see an opportunity as a result of the massive amounts of money currently being outlaid by non-government agencies and the United Nations as well as other governments for expenditure in East Timor. It would be folly for these people not to believe that they have to create partnerships with the East Timorese communityâthat the benefits which flow from this expenditure should be to the East Timorese community. The primary objective of these funds is the East Timorese community. The non-government organisations involved with East Timor should ensure that they develop framework agreements with the East Timorese communityâin the first instance, with the CNRT. They need to develop protocols for operation which ensure that the CNRT and the East Timorese community are involved in their decisions and the way in which they operate on the ground as well as in the decisions of the United Nations and its agencies. It is imperative that, if we are to advance the cause of the East Timorese in a way which they would want, we ensure that their advice is understood, that their views are properly appreciatedâand that they own the process and the process is not owned by another colonising power.

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak in the grievance debate on the issue of East Timor and the appalling partisan behaviour of the opposition and the Labor Party. In this place several weeks ago, I stated that as a former serving member of the Australian Defence Force I was not only ashamed of the Labor opposition but thoroughly disgusted with their party political tactics. To score cheap political points with little or no regard for our national interests or for the morale of our defence forces here in Australiaâor, more particularly, of our peacekeepers in East Timorâis irresponsible and shameful. What must our Australian soldiers based in East Timor be thinking when the opposition is saying, on the one hand, `Oh yes, we do support our Australian soldiers in East Timor, ` but, on other hand, `We should have sent them before the ballot, against the wishes of the Indonesian government.'

speech.para: The Labor opposition in government would have sent our troops to their slaughter. What the opposition is demonstrating, and has been demonstrating all along, is that political point scoring is more important than the security of our Australian defence forces. I just cannot believe it. According to opposition leader Kim Beazley and the shadow spokesman for foreign affairs, we should not have waited for the UN, or the participating countries; we should have just gone into East Timor in a hostile and aggressive fashion and sent our troops to the slaughter. It is no wonder that the people in my electorate of Makin are as disgusted as I am with the Labor opposition's policy for our troops. The opposition now seek to heap blame on the coalition and our Prime Minister for imagined wrongdoings and incorrect handling of foreign affairs.

In the Financial Review today, we have the member for Werriwa actually attempting to rewrite history. He says that we should ignore what has happened over the past 25 years in East Timor, particularly under Whitlam and Keating, that Labor should wrap up all of their successive policy failures in a bundle and not feel guilty. He wants us to disregard all of that, forget Whitlam's and Keating's record, and blame the past and present problems on Spain and Portugal. Let us not forget that, as Prime Minister of the day, Keating, through his business dealings with Indonesian businessmen, ensured his piggery was sold with huge profits, even though the Commonwealth bank had written off debts of $20 million for the piggery.

This was at a time when our farmers were being dragged from the land, as they went broke during `the recession we had to have', when we had record interest rates of 22 per cent in some cases for our farmers. He wants everybody to forget those details. He wants to wrap everything up in a bundle and delete it, in the usual fashion that the Labor Party does. He then makes the extraordinarily erroneous claim that `East Timor is a consequence of the Howard government's foreign policy failings.' The opposition needs to get a reality check, which I am sure the Australian electorate will give them, and I know they already are.

What Mr Howard, as our Prime Minister, is responsible forâin the Prime Minister's own wordsâis Australia playing a principled and honourable role, acting in a constructive and balanced way. The operational readiness of the Australian forces meant that we were able to respond promptly to the United Nations request to both participate in and lead the multinational force. This is the truth of the issue and history will record it as such. When issues of national security arise, as they have done with East Timor, the safety of our defence forces is of paramount importance. Leaking of documents and cheap political point scoring does nothing for our security, for our national interest or for the morale of our defence forces serving overseas and their families and friends. I will make it one of my priorities to inform all of my electorate of the callous way in which the Labor opposition would have our defence forces treated.

The most frequent comments by constituents have been that public figures, such as Mr Keating and Mr Beazley, should stop trying to make political capital out of this situation and get behind our peacekeepers. More tellingly, I have heard many people on talkback radio, who are Labor supporters, expressing their disgust with Paul Keating for the words that he has used and with Kim Beazley for failing to condemn Keating more strongly than he has. These Labor supporters are right to be concerned.

There are times in the life of our nation when partisan politics is necessarily put aside in the national interest. At no time is it more crucial to observe this principle than when young Australian lives are at stake. Of course, Australia has a robust democratic tradition and the people of Australia would tolerate dissent on this issue if there were substance to it but, there is the pity: there is none, and the Labor Party simply has no credibility on this issue.

I have said previously that the approach of the government to the East Timor question has been by far the most principled of any government since East Timor was integrated into Indonesia nearly a quarter of a century ago. No government before us was prepared to tackle the issue with the view to what was best for the people of East Timor. Policy was driven by pragmatism and expediency. By contrast, Prime Minister John Howard and foreign affairs minister Alexander Downer have worked tirelessly to find a solution to the East Timor question which will best serve the interests of the East Timorese people.

The letter from our Prime Minister to President Habibie in December 1998, on which Mr Keating rested so much of his case, made clear that the Australian government favoured direct negotiation between the Indonesian government and representatives of the East Timorese people, with a long-term view to a ballot on independence. Australia was not pressuring Indonesia into an early ballot, as some critics would apparently have it. The subsequent decision by President Habibie and foreign minister Alatas to proceed to a ballot sooner rather than later presented our government with a challenge, to support the process being put in place by the Indonesian government, giving the East Timorese a vote on their own future, or to oppose this process and effectively say to the East Timorese people that Australiaânot Indonesiaâwas now standing in the way of giving them a voice in their own future.

The answer to this dilemma was clear. No responsible government could oppose a proposition to allow people to participate in a ballot on their own future. It is absurd to suggest that any alternative Australian government would have done this. The task that we were then faced with was to take whatever steps we could to ensure that the ballot was conducted in a safe and transparent manner. In this context, we sought and received undertakings from the Indonesian government, President Habibie and foreign minister Alatas that the safety of the East Timorese people would be assured during the conduct of the ballot and after the result was known.

Herein lies the second and more irresponsible criticism from the Labor Partyânamely that Australia should have insisted on a peacekeeping presence during the conduct of the ballot. It is a matter of record that this matter was raised with the Indonesian government and that it was firmly rejected. By continuing to insist on it at that point would have guaranteed that the Indonesian government cancelled the ballot altogether. To have tried to insert peacekeepers over the refusal of the Indonesians would have amounted to an invasion that would have resulted in the slaughter of our Australian troops. I will just repeat that: it would have amounted to an invasion that would have resulted in the slaughter of our Australian troops. We would have been facing not simply a hostile militia but an openly hostile Indonesian military and government.

History will record this as a most unredeeming period for the Australian Labor Party. In the context of what they have acknowledged to be the most dangerous military operation by Australian forces since the Vietnam War, they have put on the thinnest veneer of bipartisan support for the government's policy in East Timor while undermining it at every turn. That the opposi tion has been unable to raise itself above petty politics at such a crucial time for Australia is a source of deep dismay to the people in my electorate of Makin and to Australians everywhere.

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, I know the matter of executive salaries is of concern to you. Most of the executives at the Macquarie Bank at a senior level earn salaries of between $400,000 and $500,000 per annum. This should be compared with the Prime Minister's salary of $240,000 per annum. I do not think it is churlish of me to suggest that they are doing very nicely, but that is not all.

speech.para: There is a profit sharing scheme which commences when the bank earns more than eight per cent on shareholder equity. In recent years, because of the extraordinary deals that the Macquarie Bank has secured with the state government of Victoria, the bank has been earning between 25 and 26 per cent returns on shareholders' funds. The result has been the creation each year of a massive profit pool to be shared around the top 70 or so executives. Each of the senior executives receives a base figure of around $400,000, plus extra for special performance. In 1998, this meant that more than 40 Macquarie Bank senior executives had total incomes of $1 million or more. Indeed, in 1998, seven senior executives had total incomes of more than $2 million. One of the main beneficiaries, the chief executive of Macquarie Bank, Mr Allan Moss, saw his salary in 1998 increase from over $498,000 to a total of $3.7 million.

The question that arises is: who is the one person whom they have most to thank for these massive salaries? The answer is Mr Alan Stockdale, the former Treasurer of Victoria. His motto has been: if it is owned by the people of Victoria and it moves, sell it. In fairness to Mr Alan Stockdale, he has been true to his word. He sold our electricity generators and distributors and our gas distribution business. He sold the Grain Elevators Board. He sold our equity in the Portland aluminium smelter. He sold Victoria's pine plantations. He commenced the sell-off of our hospitals and water supply utilities and had plans to privatise our schools. He also floated Tabcorp.

The total sell-off was in excess of $25 billion in a period of seven years. How did these sell-offs benefit Macquarie? For starters, Macquarie Bank was paid a fee of $25 million for advising on the $1.7 billion City Link project. Second, Macquarie Bank was an active participant in the successful consortium which tendered for the $4.76 billion Loy Yang A electricity generator.

Then we have Macquarie Bank's asset and infrastructure group. The asset and infrastructure group is divided into three separate businesses. They include project and structured finance, infrastructure and specialist funds and Macquarie capital. During the past 12 months, this group has provided advice on the sell-off by the federal government of Sydney airport and the sale by the Victorian government of Victoria's rail freight. The Macquarie Bank asset and infrastructure group has equity in Victoria's Loy Yang A power station and Sydney's M2 and airport motorways. The asset and infrastructure group was responsible for the float of Transurban, the company that operates City Link.

This asset and infrastructure group also advised the Kennett government in 1997 on the sale of the state government's 25 per cent holding in the Alcoa aluminium smelter at Portland and earlier, in 1993, on whether the Transport Accident Commission should be sold. Macquarie Bank has also acted as local adviser to two of the foreign consortiums who wanted to purchase parts of Victoria's public transport system.

So in all these ways decisions of the then Treasurer of Victoria, Alan Stockdale, enriched Macquarie Bank. What do we find now? Mr Stockdale, the same Alan Stockdale whose asset sell-off so enriched Macquarie, has now been appointed to the position of chairman and chief executive of none other than the Macquarie Bank's asset and infrastructure group! This is the same Mr Stockdale who, when he was Treasurer of Victoria, awarded a section of the Macquarie Bankâthe Macquarie and Computer Fleet Managementâa $150 million contract for the leasing and management of the Victorian government's computer system.

I understand that senior executives on salaries equivalent to what Mr Alan Stockdale will be earning all received incomes in 1998 of around $2 million. Indeed, according to Mr Terry McCrann in the Herald Sun on Thursday, 7 October:
The person he [Mr Alan Stockdale] will work closest with, who runs the asset and infrastructure group, got $2.9 million.
Mr McCrann went on to say that:
. . . were Stockdale just to turn up to work each day he would pocket at least $1.5 million.
And if he were to put some real runs on the board he could easily earn $3 million, and even more.

It is understood that, in addition to the Macquarie Bank appointment, Mr Alan Stockdale is contemplating joining other boards. The question that arises in relation to the Macquarie Bank appointment is: what are the terms and conditions of the contract that he has entered into? Is he merely receiving a base salary and a performance pay based on future services, or is he receiving an up-front bonus in return for what he delivered for Macquarie Bank while he was still Treasurer of Victoria?

The Victorian state election conducted on 18 September sent a clear message from the electors to the Kennett government that they had had enough of the secret state. Voters called on the government to open their books and disclose the Intergraph contract, disclose the Grand Prix contract, disclose the casino contract and disclose the Austin Hospital privatisation contract. Premier Kennett says he has changed now. He says he is going to restore the powers of the Auditor-General which he took away. He says he is going to restore the freedom of information laws which he gutted and stop the abuse of the commercial-in-confidence category to hide information. He gets his chance now. He has an opportunity to demonstrate his bona fides to the electorate by insisting that his close friend and colleague, former Treasurer of Victoria, Mr Alan Stockdale, do the right thingâopen the books and disclose his contract with the Macquarie Bank.

While the people of Victoria have watched their assets sold off and their schools, hospitals and roads neglectedâparticularly in regional and rural Victoriaâthey have simultaneously watched the Macquarie Bank grow fat on lucrative contracts provided by the former Treasurer of Victoria, Mr Alan Stockdale. The $25 million commission paid to the Macquarie Bank would have been well spent on roads, hospitals, police stations and schools in regional Victoria. But of course Victorians saw none of that and now Mr Alan Stockdale wants his share.

For the Macquarie Bank to now reciprocate the Victorian Treasurer's generosity with anything from a $400,000 to $3 million salary is disgraceful. This is after Victorians paid $25 million to Macquarie Bank to sell off our roads and major contracts in our computer services as well as an equity stake in our electricity generators and City Link. Has Victoria really sunk to this?

A minister of the Crown should not be able to benefit with a job from a bank or company that has been awarded major commissions or contracts by the government. It certainly should not happen when he has been the minister responsible for the awarding of those contracts. In the United States, I understand it is illegal for government advisers to leave and immediately start working as lobbyists or advisers for companies or banks negotiating with government.

There are other matters of concern. Is it not the fact that Mr Laurie Cox is a director of Macquarie Bank and that he is the one who has personally recruited Alan Stockdale? This is the same Laurie Cox who is chairman of the world's biggest toll road company, Transurban, a position he was supported into by Premier Kennett. This is the same Laurie Cox who Premier Kennett has described as one of his stockbrokers and who we know, courtesy of Stephen Mayne, delivered some 20,000 Yates shares after a phone call from Premier Kennett when ordinary Victorians were unable to obtain shares. Stephen Mayne's web site describes the Transurban float as `the best example I've ever seen of fat cats and insiders making millions from a business which relies on ordinary citizens paying up . . . Mr Cox has profited to the tune of more than $2 million'.

We know the Kennett government has given Transurban special treatment. It plans to reduce the number of lanes on Footscray Road and take other traffic management measures to funnel traffic on to City Link. We know it has turned a blind eye to Transurban's numerous breaches of its undertakings to the Victorian communityâthat the Moonee Ponds Creek would be naturalised, its massive downward revision of projected travel time savings, its ugly and third-rate noise walls, its promise that Western Link would be open way back in May, its introduction of a complex structure of fees and charges more worthy of a bank.

It has long been a matter of concern to Labor that the Kennett government has been running dead on holding Transurban to its promises and that the public interest has run a poor second to Transurban's private interest. The Auditor-General of New South Wales said that one day there would be a need for a royal commission into the Kennett administration. Mr Stockdale's appointment by Macquarie Bank brings that day closer.

talk.start.para: âFranklin Roosevelt reminded us that `democracy is not a static thing. It is an everlasting march'. Whatever happens on 6 November, the republic referendum before the Australian people represents a missed opportunity. We are being asked to embrace the mood of the new century, to reflect on almost 100 years of Federation and to draw on symbolism and identity to make a constitutional change.

speech.para: Opponents to the referendum proposal point to our constitutional history, the performance of our system of government over generations, practicalities of the status quo and deficiencies in the proposition to reject this push for change. Whilst I am a relaxed republican, the model for the selection and parliamentary appointment of our head of state has me underwhelmed. It offers neither the genuinely minimalist change of a McGarvie-like model nor the virtue of citizen participation offered by direct election.

The chance for greater involvement of Australians in the governing of our country is the missed opportunity. This mood will not dissipate and is not contained to questions about our head of state. The editorial in the 9-10 October Weekend Australian recognised that the direct election of the President `is an inherently democratic procedure, well in tune with the Australian spirit'. The current republican debate need not be the only avenue to express this Australian spirit identified by this leading newspaper. We should embrace the imperative of greater community involvement in the governing of our nation as our nation's democratic goal for the new century.

Australia began this century boasting the world's best practice Constitution and governing institutions. Our constitutional founders searched for what was best for our new nation and its component colonies and what its citizens would embrace and proudly protect. With this same attitude and approach today, we would not be being asked to vote on a constitutional change which further institutionalises power in the hands of those who already possess the greatest share of influence, control and access to the levers of government. We would be debating ideas about how to better align our governing systems with the legitimate expectations of the Australian electorate.

I propose a constructive way forward that embraces the Australian spirit of democratic involvement through the introduction of a new instrument that enables electors to present legislative proposals to the parliament. These `people's polls' would enable supported proposals to pass the first reading stage of the legislative process in the House of Representatives and give electors a direct influence over the governing of our nation.

This idea of direct democracy is right for our time and is entirely consistent with the Australian spirit. While the strength of the idea is obvious to the Australian people, it is also the biggest obstacle faced by supporters of the yes republican case. Rather than try to ignore the broad community support for the direct election model, the yes republicans should recognise the strong democratic character of the Australian spirit and seek to embrace this enduring desire of electors to be able to more directly influence the governing of our country.

My interest in direct democracy dates back long before my election to this place. It started with the embrace of the concepts at a local government level guided by research that identified 78 per cent of the local community believed that the electoral system would be enhanced if the public could vote on particular issues and policies, as well as voting to elect representatives.

Australians are not apathetic by natural disposition. However, it can be argued that indifference is an intelligent response to a circumstance over which a person has little influence. This can be changedâby providing the democratic instruments to re-engage individuals in the governing of our nation beyond the event of elections. Contemporary Australia embraces the values and ideals of political freedom, choice, personal engagement and achievement, individual worth, mutual responsibility and the sense of communityâa new type of citizenship.

We can renew support for our democratic and parliamentary institutions by enhancing the stake and influence electors have in them with `people's polls' as the cornerstone. This Australian version of direct democracy is clear, simple and right for our time. Direct democracy delivers the direct access to political decision making that informed and educated citizens want. It sits alongside and supplements a healthy system of representative democracy where elected members remain the principal means of translating the needs and interests of citizens into good government. There is no more Liberal idea than providing an opportunity for the hands of the governed to be placed on the levers of government. Here is how we would do it.

A petition containing the signatories of three per cent of Australians eligible to vote could trigger a poll. A minimum proportion of signatories from each state and territory would demonstrate genuine national interest. A requirement to register intended propositions would ensure that the petitioners presented authorised and accurate material when seeking signatories to activate the electoral processes. The poll would be held in conjunction with the next federal election subject to the proposal having `qualified' not less than three months before polling day.

For the proposal to be endorsed by the electorate, a total majority combined with a majority vote in the majority of states and territories should be required. Such a result would be valid only if not less than 25 per cent of those eligible to vote chose to participate in the poll. The valid endorsement of a proposal would be presented to this House, the House of Representatives, the people's house, via a reworking of standing orders 211 to 216 as a bill deemed to have been introduced and read for a first time. The government would be called upon to accompany the bill with a statement about whether it is prepared, not prepared or conditionally prepared to recommend any necessary appropriation.

Issues of precision in the drafting and associated claims that the mechanism is only accessible to those who can fund a team of lawyers would be overcome by the goodwill and guiding hand of the parliament's officers resourced to assist. The government may choose to support, amend or reject the proposal and carry the political responsibility that accompanies such a decision. Rejection of a validly endorsed proposal or amendments against the spirit of the proposal would no doubt be the subject of debate and reaction at the next election.

Critics, commentators and even some of my own colleagues are likely to selectively draw from international experience to deride the concept of direct democracy. But the design of this proposal draws from the experience of others, recognises our constitutional foundations, complements our representative democratic systems and provides a distinctly Australian style of direct democracy.

`People's polls' would not act as a referendum on the introduction or amendment of a law. It places a bill for such a new law or change to an existing law squarely before the parliament and the elected representatives to determine the bill's ultimate fate. The government of the day has the opportunity to embrace the proposition in full or in part, align the bill's provisions with its broader economic strategies, policy direction and other obligations. `People's polls' are entirely complementary to the representative democracy that is the backbone and workhorse of our system of government. The mechanism would enhance the functioning of our representative democratic model by providing electors with `insurance' if those elected to pursue the public interest fail in this task in the eyes of the Australian people.

With the `people's poll' proposition supported by the electorate presented as a bill before this House, our constitutional settings are respected and renewed. It is a form of direct democracy with training wheels that will enable our mechanism to evolve as our experience builds, as our participation matures and as the community confidence develops in a way only experience can produce. This approach dismisses any suggestion that constitutional change is a necessary precondition for direct democratic reform. It also enables the government of the day to respond to the expressed will of the people while preserving the duty and responsibility of the parliament.

Combining direct democracy as the natural tool that accompanies our promotion of civic and personal responsibilities and contemporary values and ideals would be our `new citizenship'. Moreover, embracing `people's polls' as part of the republican debate would actually deliver a tangible dividend to the Australian people. It would enable the yes republicans to offer meaningful citizen involvement in the governing of our country alongside its model that fails to respond to the public's wish for a say. It would underwrite the `yes plus' camp's claim that we can revisit the presidential appointment process. The citizens themselves could activate a further review.

For the direct electionist, `people's polls' would guarantee the opportunity to put this view at some point in the future. I would argue that `people's polls' are a more accurate and meaningful reflection of the desire for greater democratic involvement than the direct election of our head of state. For monarchists, `people's polls' represent democratic reform that they could support that best accords to community attitudes for greater involvement in the governing of our country. Embracing the concept would move the republican campaigns beyond the sloganeering and jingoistic appeals to the electorate that currently characterise the campaign. Let the merits of the republican debate decide that issue.

Let us embrace `people's polls' as the practical and tangible instrument for greater democratic involvement and connectedness the Australian electors are seeking. `People's polls' are a means to deliver the democratic spirit all sides of the republican debate are trying to exploit to advance their cause. The strength of this idea is that it is real, substantive and renders pure symbolism a very poor substitute for genuine democratic reform. Direct democracy's capacity to ensure that both electors and the elected have their hands on the `levers of their government' may not be the only way of providing for perfect government, but it is a giant step in the right direction. Those political advocates of the republican model cannot ignore the Australian spirit. I seek their consideration of this proposal. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThere are only 26 days before Australians vote in a referendum that will decide whether Australia will become a truly independent nation or whether our independence will continue to be compromised by having a British monarch as our head of state, a person who is chosen not because they are the best person to fulfil that position but because of who they are, who their parents were and the blood they carry in their veins. The issue is: do we move forward as a mature nation or do we continue to wallow in adolescence? This referendum is about pride and it is about maturity. One hundred years ago, six colonies came together and decided to become a nation, and Australia as we know it was born. It is now time for us to decide to become a truly independent nation, a nation where we can all be proud to be Australian and a nation where we have an Australian as our head of state.

speech.para: Unfortunately, the debate and the referendum have been shrouded in misinformation. This is because those people supporting the no case, or opposing change, are trying to dupe the Australian people. The campaign has been deceptive. It has been full of misinformation. It has been based on scaremongering. I believe that if you win a debate you should win that debate honestly. You should win it on the strength of your arguments. You should not win it because you frighten people into supporting your position. You should approach anything you do in life honestly and you should seek to be judged on that from an honest perspective.

Currently, those people supporting the no case in the debate have been anything but honest. You can look at all the adages, all the positions and all the arguments they have put forward. Each of them are based on creating fear and deceiving Australian people. They say, `If it ain't broke don't fix it,' or `It's a politicians' republic.' If something is not broken, you can still change it. We do not say that our Constitution and our form of government in Australia are broken. We have a very fine system of government, but that system of government can be improved. If things do not change, we will be left behind. Our current system of government has served us well. It is based on the Westminster system. Now is the time for us to retain the good parts of that and to have a truly Australian system of government with our own head of stateâsomebody who is Australian, someone who is one of us and somebody who does not attain that position simply because their mother or father was there before them.

To say it is a politicians' republic is also very dishonest, and I will deal with that in more detail in a moment. There has also been the constant refusal by those people supporting the no case to even mention the Queen or her successor, Prince Charles. The most dishonest person of all in this debate has been the Prime Minister. First of all, we had a long title for this legislationâthe question the Australian people would vote onâthat was very dishonest. The first question promoted by the Prime Minister would have been for a republic with a President chosen by a two- thirds majority of the Commonwealth Parliament of Australia. That does not give any idea about what the change to the Constitution is truly about.

A committee was set up by the Prime Minister himself. That committee recommended a very different question be put to the Australian peopleâthat is, that legislation provide for an act to alter the Constitution to establish the Commonwealth of Australia as a republic, with the Queen and Governor-General being replaced by an Australian President. Unlike the first question, the second question had support from a number of quarters. The first question was only supported by those people supporting the no case. That in itself shows just how dishonest that first question was. The second question was rejected by the Prime Minister and a compromise question was chosen. The question we will be voting for on 6 November is for a republic with the Queen and Governor-General being replaced by a President appointed by a two-thirds majority of the members of the Commonwealth Parliament.

Once again, this is very dishonest because it talks about only part of the process. If you are going to put in part of the process, you should include the whole process. In our current system, the Governor-General is appointed by the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister can choose whoever he or she wants to be the Governor-General. The Prime Minister does not have to discuss that with his cabinet. He does not have to discuss it with the parliament. He does not have to discuss that with anyone. It is purely the choice of the Prime Minister. What we have at the moment is a Prime Minister's system of government, a Prime Minister's constitutional monarchy. The Prime Minister can sack the Governor-General whenever that Prime Minister chooses to. The Prime Minister is not accountable under the current processes which are not transparent.

The proposed system is a system of minimal change where the President will have the same powers as the Governor-General but the appointment process is very different. A committee of 32 will make a recommendation to the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister will then nominate the person whom he or she chooses from that short list to the parliament. That will be seconded by the Leader of the Opposition and then a two-thirds majority of the whole parliament will have to endorse that nominationâthat is, the Senate and the House of Representatives. The process is much more open and the Prime Minister is much more accountableâfar from being a politicians' or Prime Minister's republic. In relation to the dismissal process, currently the Prime Minister can dismiss the Governor-General whenever the Prime Minister chooses to. Under the proposed system, the Prime Minister can still dismiss the President but within 30 days of that dismissal the Prime Minister must explain to the parliament why he or she took that action.

Sir Zelman Cowen and former High Court Justices Brennan and Mason came out last week and said that the proposed process is a lot more accountable and a lot more open than the current situation. When the committee was taking evidence, Malcolm Fraser addressed the committee. It was very definitely his opinion that the process on which the Australian people will be voting for on 6 November is open and accountable in that the Prime Minister must explain to the Australian people his or her decisions. The only way we will have a politicians' republic is if the people elect a President. If the people elect the President, the only people who will be able to afford to run for that position will be members of political partiesâsomebody who is either a member of the Labor Party or a member of the coalitionâor, if you really wanted to let your imagination run wild, a representative of one of the big corporations, maybe Kerry Packer.

I believe that the model and the amendments to the Constitution that the Australian people will be voting on are very fair. It will not mean that we change the flag. It will not mean that Australia cannot participate in the Commonwealth Games. We will still be a member of the Commonwealth of Nations. The referendum has awakened in all Australians a keen interest in our Constitution. It is a time to determine who we are and what we want to be. It is a time to look to the future. Australian people want to understand their Constitution. I hope that, as a result of this referendum, they will. It is important that the referendum debate be honest and not based on a scare campaign. This is a chance for Australians to vote to maintain the best aspects of our current system whilst, at the same time, asserting our status as a truly independent nation with a President who will not be a politician, chosen by the Prime Minister or appointed to that position because he or she is a member of the British royal family. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âTwo years ago, after the Asian economic crisis, both the Department of Defence and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade issued white papers. When we look at those white papers from two years ago, it seems that the true impact the Asian economic crisis would have on regional security was not anticipated in the defence white paper. That is what I would like to touch on in the grievance debate today.

speech.para: The key features of the post-Cold War strategic environment in the Asia-Pacific are the demise of Soviet influence in East Asia, the rise of China as an economic and military power and the continuing presence of the United States in East Asia. Japan and India remain important regional powers which play a part in the consideration of the balance of power. Regional flashpoints include the Spratley Islands in the South China Sea, the Straits of Taiwan and the Korean Peninsula.

In the first phase of the post-Cold War era, running from 1989 to the Asian economic crisis in 1997, there was hope that economic interdependence and multilateral institutions would encourage cooperation and underpin regional stability. The Asian economic crisis has highlighted the failure of organisations like the ASEAN regional forum and APEC to contribute to economic and strategic cooperation. It was actually extraregional institutions such as the IMF and the World Bank which provided assistance to affected Asian countries. In the last sitting week, we heard the member for Holt talking about the role that he and Indonesia had played in the establishment of the ASEAN regional forum and APEC. But, as we saw during the Asian economic crisis, they were not actually able to play a role. Undoubtedly, the crisis has altered the regional balance of power. Although the bipolar distribution of power in East Asia, characterised by Chinese land power and US maritime power, has remained unaffected, China has had its status as a regional leader enhanced by its actions during the crisis and by the economic stagnation of most other countries in East Asia.

The Asian economic crisis began in July 1997 with the devaluation of the Thai baht and has altered Asia's strategic outlook dramatically. It was unpredicted and destroyed the assumption that the rise of East Asia would continue without check. Shortly after the crisis began, the Australian Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Department of Defence both issued white papers. As highlighted in the Bulletin on 3 August 1999 in an article by J. Lyons entitled `Operation Backflip', they failed to anticipate the collapse of Suharto in Indonesia and nuclear testing by India and Pakistan. Issued in December 1997, the Defence white paper, entitled Australia's Strategic Policy 1997, minimised the impact of the Asian economic crisis on regional security. I think it is important that the Defence white paper this year takes into account the failures that were made in that 1997 white paper and anticipates problems better in future.

Paul Dibb has described the Asian economic crisis as the start of the second phase of the post-Cold War order. The economic crisis has altered the central feature of Asia-Pacific stabilityâthat is, regional stability was underpinned by the rapid economic growth of East Asia. Several regimes based their legitimacy on economic growth rather than on democratic election. The economic crisis has increased uncertainty in the Asia-Pacific and undermined regional cohesion. It has also altered the regional balance of power and undermined the view that growing economic interdependence and multilateral institutions will prevent conflict in Asia.

Leadership in Asia was based on delivering economic growth without legitimacy drawn from a democratic election. That is not in all countries but in several countries. In ASEAN countries, in South Korea and in China, unending economic growth was the expectation of the population. Only Taiwan and China avoided negative economic growth during the crisis. For the remainder, the collapse of prosperity in Asia threatened the basis of those governments. Of the three countries that required IMF bailouts, democratic change has already occurred in South Korea and Thailand, and the resignation of Suharto preceded Indonesia's first democratic election since 1955. There has been democratic change there.

The Asian economic crisis has highlighted the weaknesses of regional multilateral institutions such as APEC, the ASEAN regional forum and ASEAN itself. None of these institutions played a role in addressing the economic or strategic implications of the crisis. Richard Woolcott has argued that it is too early to write these institutions off. Both APEC and the ARF are recently established, and neither was able to formulate common policies on the economic and security implications of the crisis. The ARF is at only an early stage of discussing confidence building measures and preventative diplomacy. APEC has no security discussion. ASEAN was irrelevant to the economic crisisâthat is, despite the development of those institutions, Asia was unable to cooperate on security or financial matters during the crisis. I think the jury is still out on what role they will be able to play in economic and security cooperation in the future.

Economic development and security have played an important part in regional security discussions, and there is a risk that the crisis will undermine regional security cooperation. One encouraging sign during the crisis has been China's refusal to devalue the renminbi, which would have led to competitive devaluations throughout South-East Asia. Also on a positive note, Thailand and South Korea witnessed a democratic change of government, and President Suharto was overthrown with less violence than expected.

The variable impact of the crisis on ASEAN members may increase tension within the organisation. Already within ASEAN, you see a split between some of the countries. Indonesia and Malaysia are seemingly more anti-West. With the Philippines and Thailand, this is not so. ASEAN celebrated its 30th anniversary in 1997, but I think there are now real questions about its future.

The economic crisis also has several important implications. As Geoffrey Barker pointed out in the Financial Review, Indonesia still has a significant risk of political and social disintegration. Although there have been encouraging signs, Indonesia remains poised between stability and chaos. Secondly, Thailand's economic collapse has undermined its position within South-East Asia. That may encourage Cambodia, Myanmar and Vietnam to follow a model based more on central political control rather than to follow a Thai model based on open markets. Thirdly, rivalries between ASEAN members may surface and their economic weakness may make members more susceptible to influence from an external power.

The rise of East Asia led to military modernisation programs in most countries. While there are differing views as to whether that was a benign or ominous development, the Asian economic crisis caused countries such as Thailand, Malaysia, the Philippines and South Korea to cut defence spending by 30 to 40 per cent, and Indonesia has cancelled purchases of new defence equipment. Japan has also cut defence expenditure in non-hardware areas. China, Taiwan and Singapore were less affected by the regional crisis and, as such, have continued their defence spending at pre-crisis levels. This has important implications for the balance of power and the power hierarchy in Asia.

Countries such as Thailand, the Philippines, Malaysia, South Korea and Indonesia have been reduced in their relative power and standing, while China has enhanced its status as a regional power. Although Japan contributed significantly to IMF bailouts and provided over $42 billion in financial assistance, it has still been perceived within the region as having been distracted by its own economic problems. In South-East Asia, Malaysia's economic malaise is contrasted with the continuing strength of Singapore. In North-East Asia, the weakness of South Korea may have delayed reunification and encouraged the isolated North Korean regime to delay cooperation with South Korea. Again in the Financial Review, on 7 and 8 August 1999, Geoffrey Barker reported that North Korea appeared to be planning to conduct a second long-range missile test and was continuing its program to develop weapons of mass destruction. South Korean plans for large defence expenditure and for developing a force which will allow power projection beyond the Korean Peninsula will also have to be postponed.

The United States, through the IMF, the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank, has provided leadership during the economic crisis. In April 1998, a report from the US Congressional Service stated that `a prolonged economic decline could fuel nationalism, undermine regional cooperation, and foster confrontation over longstanding territorial and other disputes'. The leadership shown by the United States has not always enhanced America's standing in East Asia. The reluctance of the United States to support an ally, Thailand, and its support for harsh IMF conditions for Indonesia may lead to anti-American sentiments in the future. In closing, the major potential problem relating to the economic crisis has been a shift in the balance of power and how that will be handled by the regional powers.

talk.start.para: âAs the 6 November referendum draws nearer, the Australian people are becoming more focused on the real issues. In discussing these issues with my constituents in the Fowler electorate, I find that their views are based on experiences which are often different from the arguments being put by the representatives of each side of the debate. My electorate of Fowler could be described as the least British of all Australian electorates. Almost half of the population are descended from non-British parents. For these people, the monarchy is seen as being essentially British and even as something foreign. That is quite the opposite to what the monarchy represents to some Australians of British descent.

speech.para: If the monarchy were totally irrelevant, this might not be a concern, but in many ways having a non-Australian head of state does influence the thinking and actions of many Australians of non-British descent. For one thingâand this is crucial in a multicultural societyâalmost half of the people in Fowler cannot expect a person of their origin to become Australia's head of state. No-one of their race or origin can aspire to that position. Australia's head of state is the sole preserve of people of British origin. Not being able to identify with a country's leadership can have a number of negative influences. I will give a few examples. Not so long ago, I was speaking with a constituent who told me that his Australian born son had gone to hisâthe father'sâcountry of origin to perform military service. When I protested that his son was born here and so was an Australian citizen, the father gave me this argument: if his son were to serve in the Australian Navy, he could serve on one of Her Majesty's Australian ships or in the Royal Australian Air Force. He said, `It is okay for you. The Queen comes from your country. Why can't my Australian born son serve in my country?' That feeling sums up the beliefs of many Australians. No-one should question their loyalty to Australia, but while ever they see Australia's head of state as someone foreign their loyalty to their own heritage will be above their loyalty to the heritage of British Australians.

This division of loyalties is having an effect on Australia's performance in a global economy. For an increasing number of people of European origin, their heritage entitles them to lucrative employment opportunities in the European Union. To maintain this entitlement and to ensure that their children have the same entitlement, a significant number hold dual citizenshipâwhere this is possibleâor, in some cases, they renounce their Australian citizenship in order to maintain their entitlement. In a global economy, it is not only ideas and capital that flow freely across borders but also people. This will increasingly mean that more and more of Australia's best and brightest will leave our shores to work overseas. This brain drain will cost Australia dearly.

What loyalty can we expect from people who cannot identify with their country of birth? When Australia's head of state is not an Australian, why should they maintain loyalty to Australia? Having a non-Australian as head of state is really the ultimate kind of dual citizenship. It must seem strangeâas our courts have again recently shownâthat, while you cannot be a member of this parliament if you have not renounced your holding of citizenship of another country, you can be head of state.

These may not be considered the main issues in the debate, but they are issues which must be addressed whatever the outcome of the referendum. If Australia is to be more than a country of convenience, more than a motel room on the global economy highway, we must have an identity and a vision of what our country is and what it represents. We must have leadership which helps to create that vision and it must share that vision as one of us. In short, we definitely must have a resident for president.

On a completely different matter, an issue which has troubled me for some time is the effect of tobacco taxes on low income families. This is an issue which, due to changes which will soon come into effect, deserves closer consideration. The changes which will levy the excise on each stick rather than the weight of tobacco will make what is already one of the most regressive taxes totally unfair. Let me say from the outset that I am a smoker, one of that now small band of members who are still hooked on the habit. But let me also say that I do not hold a brief for the tobacco companiesâfar from it.

What we have seen in recent years, in the name of health policy, has been a dramatic increase in the taxes applied to cigarettes. While these measures were undertaken by the states, the Commonwealth has taken responsibility for those taxes since the High Court found that only the Commonwealth could levy such taxes. Since taking over tobacco taxes, the Commonwealth has changed the method of calculating the tax so that it is now to be calculated per stick. This will add around a dollar to the price of a packet of 25 cigarettes, with a further 10 per cent GST is to be added next July, which will add a further 70c or 80c per packet, and then there are CPI adjustments to come. Where will it end?

A generation ago such increases would have been sufficient to bring down a government. Mr Deputy Speaker, you can imagine what the headlines would have been on the day after the handing down of a budgetâ`Workers hit: beer and smokes up'. Smoking has become a luxuryâa luxury that fewer and fewer people can afford. But that does not mean that they can give it up. If any other industry were to be taxed in this fashion, consumers would rebel and none of the goods would be sold. But with smoking, because of its addictive nature, consumers cannot just give it up. Ask any smoker and they will tell you how hard it is. But the government knows this. That is why it knows it can increase the tax and only a few will give up smoking.

Until now, smokers have had the option to buy cheaper cigarettes in larger and larger packs. But the government has closed this loophole. Now you pay the tax of nearly 20c every time you light up. The Treasury should be giving away free matches. The latest increase will add $440 million per year to the revenue. Smokers in Australia will be paying $5 billion per year in taxes that non-smokers do not have to pay. This is grossly unfair. It is a harsh and unreasonable penalty, particularly on low income Australians.

Of course there is the health argument: make cigarettes so expensive that everyone has to give them up. But where is the evidence that this is behind the small decreases in Australians smoking? In fact, the high cost of cigarettes may cause greater health problems than it prevents. For low income households, tobacco taxes divert expenditure away from what may be beneficial goods and services. When you look at the cost of tobacco taxes on a low income family, the effect is startling. At 20c per smoke, a moderate to heavy smoker will pay $5 per day in tobacco taxes. That is around $150 per month, or $1,800 per year. If both husband and wife are smokers, that is $3,600 per year. That is more than the amount of income tax paid by a single income family with two dependent children having a weekly income of $500. Low income families with two smokers will pay more in tobacco tax than they do in income tax. That is grossly unfair.

It is time for the health nazis to take stock of the cost of tobacco taxesânot just tobaccoâon the health of low income Australians. It is time that Treasury kicked the habit of exploiting smokers to the tune of $5 billion per year. And it is time for smokers to put their money where their mouth isâin a different wayâand take a stand against this exploitation.

subdebateinfo.title: Fringe Benefits Tax: Public Benevolent Institutions

talk.start.para: âI congratulate the government on the action it is taking after recognising that some public benevolent institutions are taking unfair advantage of the exemption to fringe benefits tax. It is right that we are considering proposals to prevent rorting in what I understand to be a small sector of public benevolent institutions. There is no doubt that this small sector is making things very difficult for the industry as a whole because most of the institutions are treating their fringe benefits exemption with the respect that such a privilege deserves.

speech.para: I understand that some of the big institutions are taking advantage in several ways. First of all, many are packaging an enormous component of their salariesâI have heard figures of up to 60 and 70 per centâand some are also packaging for a large number of people on the payroll. Clearly this practice is not the intent of the privilege of exemption.

The privilege of exemption of FBT given to these institutions was to enable them to attract suitably qualified staff when in competition with the private sector. Being able to package a certain component of an employee's wage meant that they could, for example, offer a potential employee a package that was worth, say, $80,000 to the employee but may cost the institution, because of its fringe benefits tax exemption, only $50,000 or $60,000.

This exemption, I must stress, was designed to assist the institution, not the individual. Like so many things in our society, we are forced to legislate down to the nth degree to prevent people from taking advantage of a situation. I believe there is a danger in meeting this problem, however, with an overreactive response. I believe we need a proper and considered response that will achieve the aims of the governmentâthat is, to prevent the rortsâbut will also allow the intent and the spirit of the original legislation to be delivered to those institutions that are treating the privilege in its proper way. There is already widespread acceptance by governments, especially in the disability area, that much of this sector is already underfunded by the state governments, and a serious attack on the bottom line that might result from severe restrictions on the fringe benefits tax exemption will have serious implications on many industries, not the least the disability support industry.

The public benevolent institution industry as a whole has recognised an unofficial benchmark of about $30,000, or around 30 per cent of the package. My understanding is that it is considered from both their side and the government's side as not an outrageous amount and that it probably meets the spirit of the existing legislation. All of the institutions that I have spoken to certainly recognise and understand the need for the reporting on group certificates of fringe benefits tax, and most appear to have no problem with this. My concern is that we would be tempted to tighten up the legislation too much too quickly. This would have a large effect on PBIs, certainly in regional and rural areas, and I would imagine in the city areas as well.

In my area, for example, we have Westhaven Industries, a big organisation that has a supported employment service as well as an accommodation area for disabled people. Nearby there is Wangarang in Orange, House with No Steps in Forbes, Glenroy Industries in Bathurst, Carlaminda in Gilgandra, and the Royal Flying Doctor Service in Dubbo and Broken Hill. These are only a few of the institutions that will be making use of the exemption on fringe benefits tax. There are many, many others doing good work for the communityâfor example, community legal centres that are too numerous to mention. However, they provide an enormous range of services to the community, from legal services to financial counselling, disability support, aged care support and many other services.

Westhaven Industries provide accommodation and employment support for between 125 and 130 people. They make pallets, tomato stakes, survey pegs, dusters, boots, slippers, underlays, doonas, saddle cloths and picture frames, to name but a few products. Like many of these institutions, they have moved from being a group run by perhaps a well- meaning manager and a board. In the past, these people may not have had the financial skills to run such an organisation in such a manner that would deliver the best outcomes for the public dollar. However, having the fringe benefit tax exemption has allowed them to employ financial controllers with the skill required to successfully run such an enterprise.

The result is that the industry is run probably at its optimal efficiency. This, in turn, takes pressure off governments' budgets which would otherwise be pushed even harder than they already are for support in these areas. Even so, there is still a recognised shortage of funding from state governments. For example, all the trainers at Westhaven who are there to support the employees are also supervisors, and they are providing hands-on work already. This severely limits their ability to provide one-on-one training for the participants who need their help. This leads to less than optimum productivity. To allow optimum productivity would enable such a facility to be self-sustaining and probably help contribute to the cost of the accommodation area, which is the main area that is severely short of funding. I am sure the state government would welcome such a relief of pressure on their funds.

A fringe benefits tax exemption limited to a grossed up amount of $17,000 would cost Westhaven Industries approximately $33,000. They would immediately have to submit funding submissions to the government so they could continue to be commercially competitive in attracting a level of expertise required to effectively manage and improve the quality of service delivery in this particular area of disability.

The Royal Flying Doctor Service is an icon in rural and regional Australia. For those people who do not know, it provides a unique service to people who live in isolated areas. It provides an aeromedical retrieval service for people, for example, who have a car accident or who fall from a horse or who have some other serious injury. They also provide primary health care in delivering regular clinics consisting of mental health nurses, diabetes nurses, general practice doctors and Aboriginal health workers as well as drug and alcohol counselling to areas that would otherwise not receive these services at all.

The community input into the funding of the Flying Doctor is enormous. Last week I had the privilege of joining about 16 young horse riders and about the same number of support staff with about a dozen vehicles in a horse ride from Bourke to Tilpa to raise money for the Flying Doctor. This type of fundraising activity is repeated all over inland Australia and some areas of metropolitan Australia and shows the regard that the Royal Flying Doctor Service is held in by these people. The private money that is given to this organisation is enormous, and it allows the contributions by various governments to be levered to provide services far above what would be provided otherwise. This is because the local people recognise what a magnificent service is provided for them by the Royal Flying Doctor.

If a large restriction on the fringe benefits tax exemption were applied to the Royal Flying Doctor, it would cost them well in excess of a million dollars. The doctors that the Royal Flying Doctor Service employ have a fringe benefit component of their salary of about $30,000. This is to provide housing and motor vehicles for the doctors who live in places like Broken Hill. These fringe benefits are certainly not used to pay these doctors an exorbitant salary. In fact, their equivalent grossed up wages would be approximately $130,000, far below what any of these doctors would expect to earn in general practice elsewhere. The beneficiary is not the individual but the organisation, and therefore the huge community that it serves.

If the ability of the Flying Doctor to supply fringe benefits tax exemption to these doctors were greatly reduced, it would severely limit their ability to recruit. This is where we come to the argument that is being used that all that is happening is that these organisations are cost shifting to the government. Some probably are, but it is my belief that most are not.

I believe a limit to the exemption of about 30 per cent of the package, or a dollar figure of about $30,000, perhaps with a limit of 30 per cent of the number of employees that can be packaged, would go a long way to solving this in a non-draconian way. I believe that would largely be supported by industries. Certainly, the reporting of fringe benefits on group certificates is something that really needs to be done in fairness to people who are not paying a proper Medicare levy, and for some who may not be contributing properly the amounts that they should in the way of child support payments.

Having this system in place will certainly address these two major concerns without having the effect of crippling areas of industry that provide enormous support to all communities but especially communities in the bush and, most importantly, industries that are providing these services to those least able to support themselvesâthe disabled, the lower socioeconomic group and, in some cases, the elderly.

I urge the government again to clamp down on the institutions that are ripping off the system. Stop those that are growing fat at the expense of ordinary taxpayers and at the expense of the institutions that are doing the right thing. A statement must be made by the government in such a way as to address the abuse but maintain the spirit in which the legislation was originally framed, that is, to assist those magnificent organisations that do so much to assist the communities they serve. The public contributions to keep these facili ties going are an indication of the great work they do and the recognition they have for doing so.

talk.start.para: âThe question is:
âI move:

speech.para: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: HMAS Albatross Stage 2 Redevelopment, Nowra, NSW.

The Department of Defence proposes to develop further the Royal Australian Navy air base by implementing a second stage of construction. This will provide purpose-built facilities and services that will improve the operational reliability and organisational functionality of this base. These works are a natural continuation of the major redevelopment of HMAS Albatross , which under the Defence stage 1 project was agreed to by the Public Works Committee in April 1998. The stage 1 works included an integrated squadron complex with HS816 Sea Hawk helicopter and HS805 Sea Sprite helicopter squadrons, an air traffic control complex, an airfield lighting system, aircraft shelters, an explosive ordnance storage complex and training and photographic centres. The design, documentation and construction of these facilities is currently progressing with completion planned for October in the year 2000.

The second stage of proposed works will provide for the upgrade of existing arrester gear, a helicopter corrosion control facility, flight deck procedural training simulators, a visiting military aircraft hardstand, perimeter security fences, a helicopter underwater escape training simulator, a gymnasium, extension of taxiway bravo and the demolition and relocation of buildings and engineering services. Future proposals for works at HMAS Albatross will address further developments or upgraded facilities extending beyond economical repair or upgrade.

The Department of Defence is currently reviewing a proposal for relocation from Sydney of 170 defence personnel in the Naval Aviation Logistics Management Squadron to Nowra, New South Wales. The two options are to provide a new 2,280 square metre facility or lease facilities in the adjacent Council-Aviation Technology Park. The estimated outturn cost of the proposal is $41 million. Subject to parliamentary approval, it is anticipated that construction will start in mid-2000 and be completed by December 2001. I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Navy Ammunitioning Facility, Twofold Bay, NSW.

The Department of Defence proposes to construct a Navy ammunitioning facility at Twofold Bay near Eden, New South Wales, to support ammunitioning and deammunitioning of ships of the Royal Australian Navy. The proposed ammunitioning facility will provide for the Royal Australian Navy's long-term east coast ammunitioning requirements following the closure of the current arrangements in Sydney Harbour at the end of 1999. The current facilities at Homebush will close to make way for the Sydney 2000 Olympics.

The Commonwealth owned port at Point Wilson, Victoria will be used for interim ammunitioning of Royal Australian Navy ships until permanent arrangements are in place.
